results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 29]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

In this film, we see the Anderson family on holidays, firstly with the kids at a horse riding school and then at a beach house, swimming, playing cricket and fishing.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:08:00 the kids learning to ride horses at a riding school
00:03:57:00 kids on the beach searching for crabs
00:04:10:00 a bucket of crabs
00:05:39:00 one of the boys on a paddle board
00:07:48:00 the girls playing cricket in the backyard
00:09:27:00 one of the boys dancing to a wireless on the patio
00:09:49:00 cooking steaks on a BBQ
00:11:28:00 the kids with a freshly caught fish
00:13:34:00 de-scaling and gutting the fish

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 25]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film presents scenes from suburban family life in Ballarat and holiday footage from the Mornington Peninsula.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:03:05:00 a child falling over as he kicks a football in a field
00:05:54:00 two children throw a fully clothed person into a swimming pool
00:08:35:00 slow-motion of three children running and jumping into a pool together
00:19:40:00 footage of child water skiing with Sorrento foreshore and the Continental Hotel in the background

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 23]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film presents footage of the day to day workings of a country Victoria cinema –including black-and-white footage of the Mary Poppins premiere in Ballarat – and group sports in rural Victoria.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:22:00 black-and-white footage of Mary Poppins opening at Vegas 70 cinema Ballarat
00:00:45:00 glamorous woman arrives in car
00:01:50:00 the snack stand
00:03:58:00 kids blowing up balloons
00:04:20:00 crowds outside the cinema

This film presents a glimpse of suburban family life in country Victoria in the 1960s.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

00:09:36:00 close-ups of children eating birthday party food
00:10:08:00 young children dancing at a party

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 24]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film presents some cinema promotional footage shot at the Ballarat drive-in and a local airstrip along with some shots from a VFL football match.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:01:14:00 close-up shot of car radio being adjusted for drive-in sound
00:06:15:00 VFL football match at Waverley park including junior footy at half-time
00:08:46:00 airplane taking off with “Superman is coming for xmas” banner behind it

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 20]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

This film presents footage of Ballarat in the 1970s and notably the last day of tram service in the area.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:11:43:00 people using 16mm camera filming trams in Ballarat
00:12:50:00 people alighting the Lydiard st tram for the last time on 19 September 1971
00:16:10:00 conductor issuing tram tickets on the last day of tram service in Ballarat

description_for_label:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film presents footage of Ballarat in the 1970s and notably the last day of tram service in the area.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:11:43:00 people using 16mm camera filming trams in Ballarat
00:12:50:00 people alighting the Lydiard st tram for the last time on 19 September 1971
00:16:10:00 conductor issuing tram tickets on the last day of tram service in Ballarat

results.title: 1914-1918 : legacy
results.creator_credit: Margaret Koval, Imperial War Museum (Great Britain), BBC-TV and KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “1914 - 1918 The Great War and the Shaping of a Century”.
1914-1918 is a seven part series from the BBC, looking at the Great War and the shaping of a century through the words of those who endured it. With the use of many letters, diaries and film we re-experience a war that involved the people of 5 continents. Narrated by Dame Judi Dench, we also hear voice-overs by Ian Richardson, Martin Landau, Wendy Craig, Tim Pigott-Smith, Chris Fairbank, Jeremy Irons, Liam Neeson, Tom Fleming, John Shrapnel, Malcolm McDowell and Imogen Stubbs reading passages from personal diaries and letters. Many historians including Dr Jay Winter provide valuable background information relating to battles and events which occurred both before, during and after, what became known as The Great War. Tape Two-Legacy contains the last four episodes of this remarkable series. Episode 4-SLAUGHTER, the battles of Verdun, the Somme and Passchendaele were three of the worst of the war, yet soldiers sought to keep their sanity with music, sport and theatre. Episode 5-MUTINY, by the start of 1917, the strain of war was affecting people on the home and battle fronts. Half of the French army mutinied. Episode 6- COLLAPSE, Germany’s war effort collapsed in 1918. Episode 7-LEGACY, the end of WW1 did little to relieve suffering across Europe. Four empires collapsed and large parts of the continent were devastated. The Peace Treaty of Versailles did nothing to ease the suffering of either the conquered or victorious people, and the seeds were sown for a second war. This was a war of attrition of men, machines and ideals. The futility of losing a generation of 9 million men who never came home, from a war many didn’t understand. National honour, fervour, and man’s greed to expand borders and dominate others led to a society which was torn asunder and would never be the same again. It affected and influenced art, music, literature and changed the history for the rest of the 20th Century.

results.title: 1914 - 1918 The Great War and the Shaping of a Century
results.creator_credit: Carol Sennett, Carl Byker and BBC
results.brief_description: This is a seven part series from the BBC looking at the Great War and the shaping of a century through the words of those who endured it. The series is narrated by Dame Judy Dench. The first part, Explosion, contains the first three episodes and details the build up to the War and the first years of the campaign. The second part, Legacy, expplores the War and the consequences of the end of the War, including the Treaty of Versailles and the seeds that were sown for the second World War.
results.title_for_label: 1914 - 1918 The Great War and the Shaping of a Century

results.title: 1914-1918 : explosion
results.creator_credit: Margaret Koval, Imperial War Museum (Great Britain), BBC-TV and KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “1914 - 1918 The Great War and the Shaping of a Century”.
This is a seven part series from the BBC, looking at the Great War and the shaping of a century through the words of those who endured it. With the use of many diaries, letters and film we re-experience a war that involved the people of 5 continents. Narrated by Dame Judy Dench, we also hear voice-overs by Ian Richardson, Martin Landau, Wendy Craig, Tim Pigott-Smith, Chris Fairbanks, Jeremy Irons, Liam Neeson, Tom Fleming, John Shrapnel, Malcolm McDowell and Imogen Stubbs reading passages from personal letters and diaries. Many historians including the series historian Dr. Jay Winter provide valuable background information relating to events and battles which occurred. Tape One-Explosion contains the first three episodes of this remarkable series. Episode 1-EXPLOSION, explores the cultural backdrop to the outbreak of war. Episode 2-STALEMATE, as the war began many experts thought technical advances in weaponry would bring a quick victory but armies resorted to trench warfare on the Western Front. Episode 3-TOTAL WAR, the battle at Gallipoli in 1915 confirmed that European conflict had expanded into the first truly global war. Many Empires and Nations would be forever changed, the social context altered and shattered, a lost generation of men and ideals. Such dramatic events that would shape and define peoples lives for the rest of the 20th Century.

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 21]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

The film contains eclectic footage from a family holiday in New Zealand, a Sherbert concert in Ararat, a Dumbo film premiere promotional parade in Ballarat, and some black and white footage of a surburban house being constructed.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:05:42:00 brief tourist shots in New Zealand: hot springs, tehokowlitu-a-tu, memorial gateway, Maori soldiers
00:07:21:00 shot of a drive-in
00:08:04:00 Astor theatre in Ararat; Sherbert concert footage
00:11:23:00 black-and-white footage of house being built
00:17:52:00 Dumbo film promotion in street parade Ballarat
